Posts.Content: Hello All, Ive been recently diagnosed with prostate cancer. My stats are posted in my signature and will update as things change. Like most guys under 50, I had not done much research about prostate cancer until the last couple of months. I found this forum about two weeks ago and did a lot of reading. I like how active, professional and helpful you guys have been and some of the information has been useful. I will add my story and update in hopes that it can help others. Im 43 and married with a 2 year old daughter and a 5 year old son. I started the family later in life but I was having too much fun in my 20s and then had to find the right girl. I ended up marrying a good friend and someone that I even dated over 20 years ago. Early detection with cancer is the key. It greatly increases the chances of a successful treatment. There were two major factors that allowed me to find the cancer early. First was The Wife. Without her trying to keep me alive, I wouldnt be doing PSA tests and probably missing most of my yearly checkups. The next is family history. Due to my father having prostate cancer, I started doing PSA tests and prostate exams around age 40. My father had open prostate surgery at 64 and is now 76 and still going strong. I was initially worried about the biopsy. Not necessarily about the results but for the procedure down there. The procedure was more uncomfortable and not really painful and took about 10 minutes. Not as bad as I had imagined. Good thing I dont embarrass easily as the assistant was cute and looked like she was about 25. I also had another first as I needed to perform my first enema before the biopsy. Was just hard to get into the right position and in my house some privacy. One of our dogs kept barking at the bathroom door to come in and see what I was doing. My urologist is professional and a great guy. The only medical issues in recent years, other than slightly high blood pressure, have been in the bad region of my body. Kidney stone removal, vasectomy and now prostate cancer. I have to stop seeing him and told him as much. Why couldnt it be something wrong with my foot When the results of my biopsy came in, it was not that hard for me to deal with emotionally. There is a history of cancer on both sides of my family and knew a long time ago that I would probably get it in some form or another. I also solve problems every day as I run the operations for a manufacturing company. This is just another problem to solve. Im not saying that it didnt affect me at all as there were a few restless nights, but easier than if it was a complete surprise. I am planning on doing the Da Vinci surgery with Dr. Vipul Patel in Orlando, FL. I have a consultation appointment scheduled in a few weeks. Luckily he is only about 2 hours away. My urologist who has performed a few hundred of these surgeries, recommended Dr. Patel mostly due to my age and the experience of the other doctor. I have done a lot of research and believe he is one of the leaders and most experienced in the world with over 10,000 surgeries performed. I am comfortable that I made the right decision. More information to come as my journey continues Chris
Posts.Signature: Born: 1972 5-10, 185lbs Father had Prostate Cancer with open surgery at age 64 June 10, 2016 (Normal PSA Screen) PSA: 5.48 June 21, 2016 (4Kscore Test) PSA: 6.05 Free PSA: 0.7 Free PSA%: 12% 4K Score: 12% July 19, 2016 Biopsy: 10 samples taken Right base: Rare atypical prostatic glands which disappear on deeper levels Right Mid Medial: Adenocarcinoma, 15% of tissue, Gleason 3+3=6 Left Base: Adenocarcinoma, 3% of tissue, Gleason 3+3=6 Left Mid Medial: Adenocarcinoma, 10% of tissue, Gleason 3+3=6 Right Lateral Base, Right Lateral Medial, Right Apex, Left Lateral Base, Left Lateral Mid, Left Apex: Benign Prostatic Tissue ProstaVysion Score: 4 Positive on ERG Negative on PTEN Sept 21, 2016 Surgery consultation appointment scheduled with Dr. Vipul Patel in Orlando, FL. Oct 12, 2016 Surgery scheduled for January 20, 2017

Posts.Title: 43 years young and joining the Club

Posts.Content: Hi Jeff, Thank you for the update. As someone that is planning to have surgery, the more details the better. I don't mind how "gory" they are as it gives us better insight on the recovery and possible issues. I even watched a 90 minute YouTube video of Dr. Patel narrating a surgery for training purposes. Dr. Patel will also be my surgeon and I have a consultation with him next week. Good luck on the recovery and keep the information coming, good or bad. Chris
